items.title: sphinx.ext.viewcode extension doesn't work when making singlehtml
Missing functions of package after `index`.
items.body:
Hi hi! We're using AutoAPI in CircuitPython and are hitting a weird bug where functions aren't listed in a toctree consistently. I think this has to do with the order the files are processed.

Here is a small-ish repo case. Click into the `ulab` entry and you'll see that only half of the modules have functions listed underneath even though they have functions.

![Screenshot_2020-07-27 ulab — Python documentation](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52649/88609228-781af500-d038-11ea-974b-95e8219ba9c8.png)

[sphinx-bug.zip](https://github.com/readthedocs/sphinx-autoapi/files/4985473/sphinx-bug.zip)

Thanks!

items.title: Methods fail to get documented with autodoc-style directives in Sphinx 3.1+
items.body:
`tests/python/test_pyintegration.py::TestSimpleModule::test_manual_directives` fails and raises warnings such as

```
error while formatting signature for example.Bar.method_okay: 'NoneType' object has no attribute '__dict__'
```

It looks like support for overloads in autodoc has broken this test, so we probably need to implement our own overload support.

items.title: Module autosummary not showing
items.body:
I'd like to show autosummary tables using sphinx-autoapi, and I'm using the `"show-module-summary"` option as
```
autoapi_add_toctree_entry = False
autoapi_python_class_content = "both"
autoapi_options = [
    'members',
    'show-inheritance',
    'show-module-summary',
    'special-members',
    'imported-members',
    'inherited-members',
]
```
but no tables are appearing in the built docs. I assume I should be seeing a table of contents for each package or module, with each item accompanied by (some of) the docstring for that item.

I'm using the "pydata_sphinx_theme" theme

items.title: fix for issue #193?
items.body: I saw that there are plans to fix https://github.com/readthedocs/sphinx-autoapi/issues/193, but from https://github.com/readthedocs/sphinx-autoapi/issues/210 it is unclear if the fix for 193 made it into the latest pip release. I am running into the `'ImportFrom' object has no attribute 'getattr'` issue, so just wanted to check on the status of the fix. Thanks!

items.title: Is this extension `parallel_read_safe=True`?
items.body:
This extension does not return metada on the `autoapi.extension.setup` function. By default, Sphinx marks `parallel_read_safe=False` and `parallel_write_safe=True`.

So, when running Sphinx with `-j auto`, if this extension is installed in the project, it will always run in serial:

```
WARNING: the autoapi.extension extension does not declare if it is safe for parallel reading, assuming it isn't - please ask the extension author to check and make it explicit
WARNING: doing serial read
```

It would be good if we can find out if this extension is parallel safe or not and define it explicitly.

Reference: http://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/stable/extdev/#extension-metadata

items.title: Docstring not picked up when using typing.overload
items.body:
When I use [`typing.overload`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/typing.html#typing.overload) on a method, I don't get any documentation for that method, presumably because the first variant of that method is empty **this is slightly incorrect - see comment below**

If I move the docstring to the first overloaded variant (or copy it to all the variants), it builds the docstring, but it shows the type signature of only the first variant whereas it should show all of them

I'm using

Sphinx 3.0.4
sphinx-autoapi 1.3.0
sphinx-rtd-theme 0.4.3

items.title: Change title of the root index
items.body:
Is is possible to rename the template or use a user template for the root index of the generated RST? The template is located at: 
[autoapi/templates/index.rst](https://github.com/readthedocs/sphinx-autoapi/blob/master/autoapi/templates/index.rst), but I don't see an option to change this title.

I have a project with C++ and Python APIs, and I would like to name the headers of each sub API appropriately. For instance, I want to name the `sphinx-autoapi` generated API header to be `Python API Reference`. I'm also using [Exhale](https://exhale.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) for the C++ API, which allows specifying a title through the `rootFileTitle` argument.

Apologies if there's a simple answer to this - I was not able to find anything.

items.title: scoped missing from template module.rst
items.body:
In module.rst template, ``content`` is an outer block with inner blocks like ``classes``. The ``scoped``
keyword is missing so that the inner block processes empty lists. See: 

https://jinja.palletsprojects.com/en/2.11.x/templates/#block-nesting-and-scope_

I'm going to make a branch and fix this, unless any developers object.

items.title: sphinx.ext.viewcode not working ?
items.body:
For our project documentation we would like to show [Source] links next to the API references. In principle ```sphinx.ext.viewcode``` should be able to provide this, however it doesn't seem to be working so far neither on my local build nor on the readthedocs build. From the references to ```sphinx.ext.viewcode``` I have found so far, none is using sphinx-autoapi, they all rely on autodoc (e.g. https://github.com/readthedocs/readthedocs.org/issues/2139).

Anyone with some experience on this topic?

items.title: Imported classes within module cause WARNING: xxx specified for inheritance diagram is not a class or module
items.body:
I am having a problem in a larger project, but tried to condense it to a minimal example:

With the following setup

```
.
└── lib
    ├── __init__.py
    └── something.py
```

`__init__.py`:

> ```Python
> from .something import Something
> ```
> 

`something.py`:

> ```Python
> class Base:
>     pass
> 
> class Something(Base):
>     pass
> ```

I am getting
> WARNING: lib.Something specified for inheritance diagram is not a class or module

Importing the class to one level above has the goal to condense the user-facing parts to a more concise API, this is currently a bit subverted since the imported classes are then not fully documented, only the originals are. And the warning is a bit misleading...

items.title: Issue with private inheritance in generated rst
items.body:
Hi, I've been trying out this tool on a couple of projects where I'm trying to simplify and consolidate the documentation procedure and it's been working quite well.

However, I've run into a small issue with a part of the code involving generation of inheritance diagrams where it appears that the jinja templating is expanding into invalid rst, resulting in the following warning:
```
WARNING: Explicit markup ends without a blank line; unexpected unindent.
```

Here is the configuration I'm using:
```python
 autoapi_type = "python"
 autoapi_python_use_implicit_namespaces = True
 autoapi_dirs = [
     "{}".format(os.getenv("PYTHONSOURCE")),
 ]
 autoapi_add_toctree_entry = False
 autoapi_keep_files = True
 autoapi_options = [
     "members",
     "undoc-members",
     "private-members",
     "show-inheritance",
     "special-members",
     "show-inheritance-diagram",
     "show-module-summary",
 ]
 autoapi_ignore = ["*migrations*", "*conf.py", "*setup.py"]
 autoapi_template_dir = "_templates/autoapi"
```

And here is an example of the generated rst:
```rst
 .. py:class:: Prompt(completekey='tab', stdin=None, stdout=None)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
    Bases: :class:`cmd.Cmd`                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
    .. autoapi-inheritance-diagram:: common.prompt.Prompt                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         
       :parts: 1                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
 :private-bases:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
    Class defining command line interface prompt.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            

    .. note ::                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
       This is a base class and it can (should) be extended                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  
```
which results in the following docs (using `sphinx-rtd-theme`)
![autoapi-default](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5197820/78884931-02285900-7a5c-11ea-9e9b-b8249f32efa5.png)

and here is what I would expect it to look like:
```rst
.. py:class:: Prompt(completekey='tab', stdin=None, stdout=None)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
   Bases: :class:`cmd.Cmd`                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
   .. autoapi-inheritance-diagram:: common.prompt.Prompt                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          
      :parts: 1                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              
      :private-bases:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
   Class defining command line interface prompt.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             

   .. note ::                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
      This is a base class and it can (should) be extended                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
```

If I modify the `autoapi/templates/python/classes.rst` template I can get the expected behaviour (but I'm not an expert in jinja template syntax, so I don't know if it is the "correct" way to fix the root issue)

```diff
14c14,16
<       {% if "private-members" in autoapi_options %}:private-bases:{% endif %}
---
>       {% if "private-members" in autoapi_options %}
>       :private-bases:
>       {% endif %}
```
which results in:
![autoapi-myfix](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5197820/78885013-24ba7200-7a5c-11ea-9773-e5a067dfe34e.png)


I am working with an older code base, so using python 2.7, but I did a minimal change to fix `print` statements and was able to obtain the same result with python 3.8 (both in a `conda` environment).

For the python 2.7 env, the package versions are (removed other matches, but can add them if you think it's relevant):
```
Jinja2==2.10.1
Sphinx==1.8.5
sphinx-autoapi==1.3.0
sphinx-rtd-theme==0.4.3
```

and for the python 3.8 env, the package versions are:
```
pip freeze|egrep -i (sphinx|autoapi|jinja)
Jinja2==2.10.3
Sphinx==2.4.3
sphinx-autoapi==1.3.0
sphinx-rtd-theme==0.4.3
```

Please let me know if any additional information would be helpful.

items.title: Unclear location for relative path in autoapi_template_dir
items.body:
According to the documentation the ``autoapi_template_dir`` option can be set to a relative path but it does not make clear what this is relative to. The most logical place would be the sphinx config dir as that is where other modules default to but this does not appear to be the case.

Please either update the docs with more information as to where the template dir is relative to or modify the base.py mapper file to expand a relative path into an absolute path relative to the sphinx config dir.

items.title: [Feature Request] support :inherited-members: and :show-inheritance:
items.body:
One of the key selling points of `autoapi` is that unlike `autodoc`, it does not need to load, run, or import the project being documented. However, `autoapi` current does not support showing inheritance or inherited members (see `autoapi_options` in https://sphinx-autoapi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/reference/config.html.

To be a viable replacement for `autodocs` in our use case, we would like support for `:inherited-members:` and `:show-inheritance:`.

items.title: Add list of PythonClass bases to PythonClass
items.body:
Currently [`PythonClass.bases`](https://sphinx-autoapi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/reference/templates.html#autoapi.mappers.python.objects.PythonClass.bases) only contains a list of strings. It would be nice if there would be another list `bases_objects` which would include the actual `PythonClass` objects similiar to the `children` list which contains `PythonPythonMapper` objects.

This would allow to display inherited attributes/methods in the API Reference. I would like to achieve something similar to [this](https://valadoc.org/gtk+-3.0/Gtk.Grid.html), where the inherited members are listed at the bottom.

items.title: Add an option to not generate API Reference for submodule/subpackages
items.body:
I personally don't include the API reference for submodules/subpackages in my documentation, because I think of it as implementation detail. All important classes/functions are exposed at the package level.

Every time I build my documentation I get multiple warnings of the form:
```
WARNING: document isn't included in any toctree
````
Also I don't like that classes/functions which are imported at package level get documented twice.

Therefore I think it would be useful, if there would be an option to disable the API generation for sub-modules/sub-packages. Something like:
```python
autoapi_generate_api_submodules=False
autoapi_generate_api_subpackages=False
```

Another possibility would be to allow file paths in the `autoapi_dirs` option. The desired behavior could then be achieved with: 
```python
autoapi_dirs=['packagename/__init__.py']
```

items.title: Not handling top level functions correctly
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
When creating documentation for a module with top level functions the generated rst file is incorrect. The generated rst is expected to have a blank line after `... function::`

**To Reproduce**
Create a module with
```
def strange():
    """
    This should be a description
    """
    
    pass

def expected():
    """
    :noindex:

    This is a description
    """

    pass
```

Here's generated rst file
```
:mod:`example`
==============

.. function:: strange()
   This should be a description


.. function:: expected()
   :noindex:

   This is a description
```

Here's expected rst file. note the space after the `... function::` line
```
:mod:`example`
==============

.. function:: strange()

   This should be a description


.. function:: expected()
   :noindex:

   This is a description
```

**Screenshots and Expected behavior**
Classic Theme:
![example-classic](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44173402/65979670-4b5b7880-e43b-11e9-9793-d57935d558ce.PNG)

Sphinx-rtd:
![example-sphinx-rtd](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44173402/65979671-4b5b7880-e43b-11e9-94d6-11d284f6155c.PNG)

**Environment info**
- OS: Ubuntu 18.04.1 LTS
- Python version: 3.6.8
- Sphinx version: 2.2.0
- Sphinx extensions: None

items.title: Make Go and .NET dependencies optional
items.body:
Hello,

Currently **sphinx-autoapi** hardly depends on *sphinxcontrib-golangdomain* and *sphinxcontrib-dotnetdomain* libraries. As example, i use this library only for documenting Python codebase and i not willing to install any extra packages. Mostly because this packages or their dependencies may conflict with other project dependencies. And it's become harder when you are using poetry and have no options to deal with this potential situation.

From negative side, this change will introduce backward-incompatible changes, all everyone, who generates documentation for Go or .NET and have plain `sphinx-autoapi` or `sphinx-autoapi==^1.1.0` in their requirements, will lose ability to generate docs after next update.

items.title: Add support for async functions
items.body: Currently we ignore ast nodes of this type completely. We should be parsing them, and in Sphinx >=2.1 we should mark them as such using the `:async:` option to `method::`.

items.title: Better type annotation formatting
items.body:
Currently we use `as_string()` to get astroid to format type annotations for us. The spacing isn't great (ie really we want `variable: type`) and also it doesn't support type annotations for function arguments (eg `# type: (int, int) -> int` would only include the return type in the documentation).
The autodoc directives also need to use the annotations.

Really we should do our own formatting so that we can get the look and features we need.

items.title: Error when resolving wilcard imports
items.body:
When a package imports from itself using a wildcard import, the extension tries to find an object with a '*' in its name. It can't so it fails with a KeyError.
Instead, we'll have to add a special case where wildcard imports instead create new placeholders under that module for everything that gets imported.

items.title: Cannot autodoc-document anything under submodules without currentmodule
items.body:
```
:mod:package.submodule

.. autoapifunction:: function

.. autoapiclass:: Class
```

Neither `package.submodule.function`, nor `package.submodule.Class` (or anything else under `package.submodule`) get documented without adding a `.. currentmodule:: package.submodule` on line 2. I have a feeling that we need to override `sphinx.ext.autodoc.Documenter.parse_name` because it might be parsing the module name out incorrectly. We might also need to be using `self.objpath` instead of `self.fullname` when we figure out which module to get the attribute from.

items.title: Document the "public API" imports in Python modules

milestone.description: Any issues to fix for version 0.6.0, which we want to release shortly after Sphinx 1.8.

items.body: Ideally module documentation would work similarly to wildcard imports. If `__all__` is specified, only what's in `__all__` should be documented, if `__all__` is not specified then all imports from the local package should be documented.

items.title: Add an option to not generate the AutoAPI landing page

milestone.description: Any issues to fix for version 0.6.0, which we want to release shortly after Sphinx 1.8.

items.body: The landing page is a great way to get users started quickly, but it is also quite ugly. We should allow for it to be removed. Possibly even having the landing page point to the documentation on how to remove it.

items.title: Add support for implicit namespace python packages
items.body: The module finder should no longer look for `__init__.py` files, and the documentation should make it clear that `autoapi_dirs` should point directly at the top level package directory.

items.title: Filter Python submodules using autoapi_options
items.body: If private-members is not included, private submodules should not be documented.

items.title: Fix compatibility with astroid 2.0

milestone.description: Any issues to fix for version 0.6.0, which we want to release shortly after Sphinx 1.8.

items.body: The Python 3 tests are failing since starting to use astroid 2: https://travis-ci.org/rtfd/sphinx-autoapi/jobs/410098167

items.title: Attributes duplicated when documented in Python class docstring
items.body:
If an attribute is documented in the class docstring and also assigned to in `__init__`, the attribute is documented twice. It should get documented only once. If it is documented in both places, I think it is fine for the choice of which docstring to use to be arbitrary.

```
class MyClass:
    """My class does stuff.

    Attributes:
        thing (object): A thing.
    """
    def __init__(self):
        self.thing = 5
```

items.title: Add support for Python exceptions
items.body: Currently exceptions are documented like normal classes. astroid should be able to let us detect when a class is an exception, and therefore we should be able to document it as such.

items.title: Filter Python base classes using autoapi_options

milestone.description: Any issues to fix for version 0.6.0, which we want to release shortly after Sphinx 1.8.

items.body: Currently the list of inherited classes is complete, and will include private classes even when `private-members` is not specified inside `autoapi_options`. We should filter the list of base classes appropriately.

items.title: Update wheel requirement

milestone.description: Any issues to fix for version 0.6.0, which we want to release shortly after Sphinx 1.8.

items.body:
When installing any package through `pip` I get a warning : `sphinx-autoapi 0.5.0 has requirement wheel==0.24.0, but you'll have wheel 0.31.1 which is incompatible.`

Using `wheel==0.24.0` however would make other packages incompatible (like tensorflow or pypandoc). `wheel` being at version `0.31.1` could this requirement be updated?

items.title: Add support for Python class inheritance diagrams
items.body:
It would be a nice feature if we could add inheritance diagrams to the generated docs for python classes. The inheritance diagram wouldn't need to extend into other projects and could stop at the immediate base class if that base class is not found within the current project.

Here is an example of inheritance diagrams that I would like to see:
https://srinikom.github.io/pyside-docs/PySide/QtGui/QAbstractSlider.html

Also notice that each of the elements in the inheritance diagram is a link to the relevant class.

I would imagine that the inheritance diagram would appear after the ``Bases:: `blah.blah` `` line in the generated class documentation.

Ideally this feature would be able to be turned on or off using constants in conf.py like the other options.

items.title: Support for Python type annotations

items.body: The astroid integration hasn't been tested with type annotations at all. We should check if they're being output at the moment, and if not then output type annotations with how Sphinx normally would.

items.body:
In mappers/javascript.py

On windows, the jsdoc command is actually named jsdoc.cmd and is not recognized by subprocess().

Proposed: 

```
subcmd = 'jsdoc'
if os.name == 'nt':
    subcmd='.'.join([subcmd,'cmd'])
parsed_data = json.loads(subprocess.check_output([subcmd, '-X', path])) 
````

Could be nice to support an optional path for these commands in conf.py

items.title: go domain: complete install prerequisites
items.body:
README.rst
Setup section
Add prerequisites for GO.
README.rst
```
GO
~~~~
Install go domain extension for sphinx.

.. code:: bash
  pip install go sphinxcontrib_golangdomain


Install the go environment (from https://golang.org/dl/).

Install a git client for your environment (e.g. from https://desktop.github.com/).

Install our godocjson tool (preprocess godoc output to JSON, in a way similar to jsdoc -X).

.. code:: bash
  go get github.com/rtfd/godocjson

Add go domain in your conf.py.

.. code:: python
  extensions = [ 'sphinxcontrib.golangdomain',...

Before running building your doc, make sure the godocjson executable is in your path.

```

items.title: extension.py: bug when auto_dirs path is absolute
Remove reference to epydoc and supporting Python 2 only

milestone.description: Any issues to fix for version 0.6.0, which we want to release shortly after Sphinx 1.8.

items.body:
The README.rst file currently says:

> Currently Implemented
> ---------------------
>  
> * Python (2 only -- Epydoc doesn't support Python 3)
> * .NET
> * Go
> * Javascript

Note ``epydoc`` is a no longer maintained Python module which has not been updated for nearly 10 years:

https://pypi.python.org/pypi/epydoc
http://epydoc.sourceforge.net/

Searching the code this is the only mention of epydoc - so I believe the README entry is out of date.

Reading the code, I think you use the Python standard library modules ``ast`` and ``tokenize`` instead, so this ought to work on Python 3 too. Indeed the ``.travis.yml`` file explicitly tests under Python 3.

items.title: Unable to detect namedtuple as a class
items.body: autodoc is able to find classes created from a call to `collections.namedtuple` and document them. Currently autoapi can't detect these classes.

items.title: Add autodoc style directives for autoapi usage

milestone.description: Any issues to fix for version 0.6.0, which we want to release shortly after Sphinx 1.8.

items.body: Using directives for this will allow for manual inclusion of auto api docs. This should still allow for a full path to be created, perhaps as a secondary option once we have this feature.

items.title: Handle __init__ files better
items.body: Instead of creating a `foo.bar.__init__` file, we should instead be operating on the `foo/bar/index.html` file directly, not the `foo/bar/__init__/index.html` file.

items.title: Ensure correct path name on objects
items.body: There is some edge case that is not accounted for that causes modules to lose the closest parent name from their full qualified name. For instance, I noticed this with the `sphinx.websupport.storage` module, which somehow creates a `sphinx.storage` object. I also noticed this with Django, so it may be fairly common.

items.title: Prefix objects with module name
items.body: The objects don't seem to have the top level module name as part of the object name. This is confusing UX

items.title: Merge __init__ into class definition
items.body: Currently, these are listed separately, so there is a class definition and then an `__init__` object under that listing. The two should be merged under the class definition.

items.title: Cleanup python templates
items.body: Don't do what .net templates do.

items.title: JSON on disk through existing build
items.body: Implement collection on objects through doctree and output a JSON file on disk for later usage feeding into search index.

items.title: Get to Python 3
items.body: By assigning a milestone and creating new issues, that show, what need to be changed. I think this will help people to contribute. Or simply update README, if it is already working

items.title: Document Python C extensions
items.body:
My project ([pysap](https://github.com/CoreSecurity/pysap/)) has two components: a pure python library and a C extension. Currently I'm using `apidoc` for building both, but wanted to switch to `sphinx-autoapi` as it's cleaner and seems a better approach than importing the modules.

I've already started playing with it in the [autoapi](https://github.com/CoreSecurity/pysap/tree/autoapi) branch, by using `sphinx-autoapi` for the python library and keeping `apidoc` for the C extension, but I don't see a clear way of integrate both documentation trees.

I'm wondering what would be the best way to support this kind of scenarios. Some ideas:
- have an API tocree node wich refers to the C extension documentation produced via apidoc, and let `sphinx-autoapi` entries be placed there (in the same line than #97).
- directly implement some kind of support for C extensions and/or allow multiple instances of `sphinx-autoapi` to be configured (e.g. one folder for a Python doc, another for a C extension one, etc.)
- allow customization of the automatically inserted `toctree` index to allow addition of externally generated API docs (e.g. via a template)

Any thoughts?

items.title: Expand ast parsing to allow for inheritance docs, data docs, and class signatures
items.body:
This is a pretty hefty issue that will probably need breaking down if it's decided that it's a good idea, but changing how Python files are parsed should bring a number of benefits:

1. Inheritance documentation: autodoc is able to list what a class inherits from and link through to that class' documentation. As far as I know, pydocstyle isn't able to determine this information. I find this to be an incredibly useful feature.
2. Data documentation: It's valid to have a module level variable and an associated docstring. I'm not actually sure if pydocstyle picks this up, but currently they aren't documented by autoapi. autodoc can find these docstring with the `autodata` directive.
3. Class signature: autodoc can display the arguments given to the constructor of a class in the class signature. This isn't always possible with parsing (eg maybe the base class exists in a file that isn't being parsed), but not using pydocstyle should allow us to pick this up at least some of the time.

items.title: Properly format Google and Numpy (napoleon) docstrings in Python
items.body:
Currently Google docstrings are inserted into the rendered rst directly, instead of being parsed by Sphinx's napoleon extension.
Sphinx implements napoleon via autodoc events. Part of fixing this issue might be to make changes to napoleon to make it easier to use outside of autodoc, though I'm pretty sure we should be able to use (https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/blob/6fa0262802a09050e09445c9fd630c69b5ad1204/sphinx/ext/napoleon/__init__.py#L326), or at least mimic it seeing as it's protected.

items.title: Allow which toctree node the entries are placed under to be configurable
items.body:
It would be nice to be able to configure which toctree node autoapi adds itself to. Currently this is hardcoded to `"index"` (https://github.com/rtfd/sphinx-autoapi/blob/5529237fb5012039d248abccdf61865aace5fb32/autoapi/extension.py#L117).
For example I have the case where my documentation is split into a user and technical section. I want the API docs to reside under the technical section rather than at the top level.

The README says

> AutoAPI will automatically add itself to the last TOCTree in your top-level index.rst.
> ...
> We hope to be able to dynamically add items into the TOCTree, and remove this step. However, it is currently required.

I don't really know what this means but it sounds like it would mean implementing a similar thing?

items.title: Introduce the notion of a hierarchy
items.body:
Currently autoapi dumps every "file" as a flat list under the toc tree. It would make more organisational sense to put each entry into a heirarchy. For Python this could be done by module, for C# (and Java/C++) by namespace.

So what autoapi currently does as

```
my_package
my_package.my_module
my_package.my_other_module
```

would become

```
my_package
    |
    |- my_package.my_module
    L  my_package.my_other_module
```

items.title: AttributeError on Python functions with unpacked arguments
items.body:
When the PythonSphinxMapper._get_arguments is called with a an object representing a function with unpacked arguments (eg `def test(one, (two, three), four):`), autoapi fails with:

```
  File "venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/autoapi/mappers/python.py", line 181, in _get_arguments
    for arg in parsed_args.args]
AttributeError: 'Tuple' object has no attribute 'id'
```

We need to change how the `arg_names` list is generated so that a single item in `parsed_args.args` (specifically a `Tuple`) can add multiple names to the list.

items.title: Is it possible to distinguish also into enumerations, operators, ..., and properties?
items.body:
Currently, autoapi differentiates 4 kinds:
* class
* exception
* method
* variable
* function

Is it possible to also differentiate into:
* enumeration
* operator
* property
* staticmethod
* classmethod

autoapi already lists exceptions in a different category, if a class is inheriting from `Exception`. This could be extended to also cover enumerations, so we can create a more precise header in the documentation for all object kinds in a module.

This is the current output:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/956109/20314175/957181e4-ab59-11e6-8b13-47eb95ade694.png)

For methods in a class I would like to have the opportunity to create subgroups for:
* operators
* properties
* static methods
* class methods

It should also be possible to select:
* public,
* protected, and
* private methods.

items.title: Deduplicate verbose headings in python templates
items.body:
Templates currently output an explicit "Package ...", "Module ..." for objects. This makes for ugly output when the module being documented starts off with a docstring:

```
"""
modulename.submodule
--------------------

Things
"""
```

As we end up with:

```
Module submodule
================

modulename.submodule
--------------------
```

The easiest way around this issue is to not output a header if there is a docstring. The more complete way to fix this issue might be to parse out the docstring, removing the first heading?

items.title: Constructs are leaking
items.body:
Functions and others seem to have their own directory in our output.

http://www.pydoc.io/pypi/requests-2.11.1/autoapi/unquote_header_value/index.html

Refs #78

items.title: Python mapper argument parsing bugs and documentation
items.body:
We aren't verifying input from pydocstyle in the Python mapper and the argument splitting is a just a simple split on `,`. Some failing cases (not verified, we still need tests/docs around the pydocstyle integration):

```
def foo(bar_a, bar_b,
        bar_c, bar_d):
```

```
def foo(bar, baz={'a': 'a', 'b': 'b'})
```
